description.narrative: Annual agreement with Church of Sweden for humanitarian activities 2013. The contribution has 4 components;RRM, CBPS, regugee support porgramme in Kenya and regugee program in South-Sudan.

Samlat årsavtal 2013 med Svenska Kyrkan.Insatsen omfattar 4 komponener; RRM, CBPS (Community Based Psychosocial Support), stöd till flyktingar i Kenya samt stöd till flyktingar i Syd-Sudan. De tre första kompenenterna är fortsättningar på pågående program 2012 medan det fjärde är ett nytt inslag 2013.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Övergripande fråga: Resultat kopplat till avsedd effekt 2014Fråga: Sammanfatta resultat relaterade till avsedd effekt (denna information kommer att skickas till Open Aid).Svar: Svenska Kyrkan har inte en övergripande resultatramverk i ansökan vad gäller RRM insatser, utan producerar individuella resultatramverk per insats som godkänns allt eftersom. Resultat av RRM insatser kommer därmed att rapporteras på specifika indikatorer bland annat framtagna av Sida, samt Sida's humanitära strategimål. I enlighet med Svenska Kyrkans årsrapport för reguljära insatser samt RRM insatser under 2013: WATER: 21, 000 persons accessing sufficient quantity of water of appropriate quality for drinking, cooking and personal hygiene SANITATION: 17,000 persons using appropriate sanitation facility. MALNUTRITION: 10,000 acutely malnourished children (severely/moderately) aged 6-59 months who received nutritional support (supplemetary/therapeutic feeding). LIVELIHOODS SUPPORT: 38,000 persons provided with income support/livelihood assets. NON-FOOD ITEMS (NFI) AND SHELTER: 32,000 persons receiving shelter support and NFIs. PROTECTION: 120,000 children and adults that were able to access protection services (survivors of sexual and gender-based violence, persons living with HIV/AIDS, children and adults having access to psychosocial support) EDUCATION: 14,000 children with access to education in emergencies. Sida HUMs strategiska mål: Goal 6: Strengthened national and local capacity to meet humanitarian needs The Church of Sweden has made a special contribution in relation to Goal 6 by using our specialist competence in CBPS and by taking an active role in the larger ACT Alliance Rapid Support Team (RST) which was activated in the aftermath of typhoon Haiyan. Traditionally in humanitarian responses psychosocial needs have been seen as secondary to material losses and something to be dealt with later; however there is growing recognition that social and psychological effects of catastrophic events are not secondary but primary dimensions of the lived experience of emergencies. Being represented in RST meant that we could front this view and support ACT requesting members to develop a response where the psychosocial consequences of the typhoon, as expressed by community members, were taken into account, and where the community’s social support systems and practices prior to the typhoon were identified so that the intervention could reactivate and strengthen these. För slutrapporten rapporterade Svenska kyrkan följande (I enlighet med mail från Svenska Kyrkan 26/9 2014 där de sammanfattar resultat från 2013)´: WATER: 24, 995 crisesaffected people accessing sufficient quantity of water of appropriate quality for drinking, cooking and personal hygiene. SANITATION: 5,600 crisesaffected people using appropriate sanitation facility. MALNUTRITION: 31,192 acutely malnourished children (severely/moderately) aged 659 months who received nutritional support (supplemetary/therapeutic feeding). FOOD: 106,865 people receiving food assistance. LIVELIHOODS SUPPORT: 6,991 households with no income sources/livelihood assets provided with income support/livelihood assets. EDUCATION: 40,477 crisesaffected school aged children and youth who received improved education opportunities. NONFOOD ITEMS (NFI) AND SHELTER: 100,376 crisesaffected people receiving shelter support and NFIs. PROTECTION: 6,219 crisesaffected children and adults that were able to access protection services (survivors of sexual and genderbased violence, separated and unaccompanied children reunited with their families, children having access to community spaces, detainees visited) COORDINATION: 327,192 crisesaffected people for which humanitarian assistance is coordinated. Sida HUMs strategiska mål: Goal 4: Increased professionalisation of humanitarian actors The Church of Sweden has made a special contribution in relation to Goal 4 through our strategic partnerships with DCA and FCA on mainstreaming of CBPS into Education and Humanitarian Mine Action. When CBPS is mainstreamed, humanitarian interventions regardless of sector will to a larger degree build on existing community support systems, take measures to reach vulnerable groups and coordinate with other agencies so at risk groups can be referred and receive available support. Working towards improved CBPS mainstreaming practices will therefore greatly benefit right holders. It also contributes to the overall quality and professionalism of an intervention as utilization of existing resources, improved right holder participation and interagency coordination has multible benefits beyond contributing to right holders psychosocial wellbeing. Our strategic partnerships will foremost contribute to increased organisational capacity of DCA and FCA, however findings and resources are also being shared within relevant clusters and networks (e.g. the Global Education Cluster Working Group) thus also benefitting other humanitarian actors. Goal 6: Strengthened national and local capacity to meet humanitarian needs The Church of Sweden has made a special contribution in relation to Goal 6 by using our specialist competence in CBPS and by taking an active role in the larger ACT Alliance Rapid Support Team (RST) which was activated in the aftermath of typhoon Haiyan. Traditionally in humanitarian responses psychosocial needs have been seen as secondary to material losses and something to be dealt with later; however there is growing recognition that social and psychological effects of catastrophic events are not secondary but primary dimensions of the lived experience of emergencies. Being represented in RST meant that we could front this view and support ACT requesting members to develop a response where the psychosocial consequences of the typhoon, as expressed by community members, were taken into account, and where the community’s social support systems and practices prior to the typhoon were identified so that the intervention could reactivate and strengthen these.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
